messageBody:
Kevin O'Sullivan wrote:

> bigMethod:
> someCode
> if (condition)
> truePart
> else
> falsePart
> end
> moreCode
> end
>
> OK - so I have test cases for my new methods someCode(), truePart(),
> falsePart() and moreCode(). Seeing as bigMethod() does nothing else apart
> from call these methods I would not need to have test cases for it -
> correct?

No. You still want to verify that it invokes those methods in the
correct sequence. I have been playing around with aggressive use of the
Commons-Collections classes "Closure" and "Transformer" to help me with
that. They are essentially blocks of code. I can use a combination of
EasyMock and these two interfaces to swap arbitrary blocks of code,
allowing me to write one tests that verifies that bigMethod() invokes
everything in the right sequence.

Now a block of code is really just some method on some collaborating
class that you haven't yet identified. Consider someCode()... is there
an object that should provide that method? If so, create it and change
bigMethod() to collaborate with it. Change bigMethod()'s class so that
it accepts an instance of this new class through a constructor
parameters or a set method. (Change the existing constructor so that it
provides the "real" implementation of someCode() by default).

Now your "overall test" for bigMethod() and substitute an empty
implementation of someCode() -- one that only says "Someone invoked
me!"-- so that whatever someCode()'s behavior, it doesn't get in the
way. Now your test passes if bigMethod() invokes someCode(). :)

It's a complicated thing, and I really should write it up better as a
test-related refactoring. I can't right now, because I have work to do.
Soon. I'll come back to it.

If you get the idea, then run with it, and if you don't... well, I tried.
